newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, Netscape fight over push power.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, Netscape fight over push power.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. and Netscape Communications Corp. Wednesday escalated efforts to move Internet software from simple Web browsers to so-called push technologies that end the need to surf the Web for information and allow users to poll Internet sites for updates.
Both companies announced partnerships for companies that want to publish directly on the Internet and corporate intranets, or self-contained company networks.

Push technology has become the lastest battleground between Internet software pioneer Netscape and the largest independent software company, Microsoft. Microsoft promotes a standard known as Channel Definition Format, while Netscape has the channel finder.

"The key thing we're doing on our site is trying to communicate to people how easy it is to create channels for Netscaster," said Rosanne Siino, vice president of corporate communications at Netscape.

Microsoft's latest strategy is to provide information suppliers a spot on its planned Internet Explorer Administration Kit 4.0 to allow corporate information managers to customize information to be delivered internally.
By taking this approach, Microsoft is providing sales opportunities for providers, but also giving corporate customers the ability to block or control the channels employees pay for and use.
Netscape said its channels provide a preview and it expects to act more as an aggregator of information through which customers can subscribe for specific information.
But increased traffic by people sending out Internet "crawlers" to check Web sites for updates are still a problem for corporations that want to avoid network congestion.
One Microsoft representative said of his company's technology, "It's really smart pulling, it's not pushing."
For more businesses that require instant data, Microsoft said users may need multicast capabilities such as the publish and subscribe technology developed by Tibco Software Inc.
Tibco said it will support Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0 and Microsoft's CDF standard to enable the broadcast of real-time information over the World Wide Web.
Tibco, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was acquired by Reuters Holdings Plc in 1994. Earlier Wednesday, Cisco Systems Inc. said it purchased a minority equity stake in Tibco.
